title: RNAi: Slicing, dicing and serving your cells - Alex Dainis

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of RNA in the cell's kitchen?

options.label: A
options.text: To translate recipes from DNA into proteins

options.label: B
options.text: To interfere with itself, a process known as RNA interference (RNAi)

options.label: C
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

multiple-choice.question: What is the process known as RNA interference (RNAi)?

options.label: A
options.text: The process by which the cell translates recipes from DNA into proteins

options.label: B
options.text: The process by which the cell chops up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

options.label: C
options.text: The process by which the cell targets matching messenger RNA (mRNA)

options.label: D
options.text: The process by which the cell interferes with itself, preventing the expression of certain genes

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the enzyme dicer in the process of RNAi?

options.label: A
options.text: To translate recipes from DNA into proteins

options.label: B
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent the expression of certain genes

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the RNA Silencing Complex (RISC) in the process of RNAi?

options.label: A
options.text: To translate recipes from DNA into proteins

options.label: B
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

options.label: D
options.text: To strip the short snippets of RNA in half and use the single strand to target matching mRNA

options.label: A
options.text: The mRNA is translated into protein

options.label: B
options.text: The mRNA is chopped up into smaller pieces

options.label: C
options.text: The mRNA is sliced up, preventing it from being turned into protein

multiple-choice.question: What was the first discovery of the process of RNAi?

options.label: B
options.text: In tiny worms called C. elegans

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of introducing a pigment-producing gene into petunias?

options.label: B
options.text: The flowers produced white patches with no pigment

options.label: C
options.text: The flowers produced no blooms at all

options.label: D
options.text: The flowers produced blooms with a different color

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential therapeutic application of RNAi?

options.label: A
options.text: To target tumor cells and cancer-causing genes

options.label: B
options.text: To translate recipes from DNA into proteins

options.label: C
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of using RNAi to target tumor cells and cancer-causing genes?

options.label: A
options.text: To translate recipes from DNA into proteins

options.label: B
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

options.label: D
options.text: To turn off cancer-causing genes and prevent the growth of tumors

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential benefit of using RNAi in medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: To target tumor cells and cancer-causing genes

options.label: B
options.text: To translate recipes from DNA into proteins

options.label: C
options.text: To chop up long, double-stranded RNA molecules

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Treaty of Ghent?

options.label: C
options.text: The treaty did not result in any significant territorial changes.

What was the impact of the War of 1812 on Native American tribes?

options.label: B
options.text: They suffered significant casualties and lost even more territory.

options.label: A
options.text: It was a decisive defeat for the US.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a notable victory for the US.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main factor leading to the US's lack of success in Canada?

options.label: D
options.text: Desire for expansion into Canadian territory.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the War of 1812 on American history?

options.label: B
options.text: It confirmed the US as an independent nation and launched the career of Andrew Jackson.

options.label: C
options.text: It resulted in significant territorial changes.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the decline of the US.

title: Math jokes explained

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the joke about binary?

options.text: There are 10 types of people in the world: those who understand binary, those who don't, and those who don't expect the joke to be in base 3.

options.label: B
options.text: A 1 and a 0 in binary look like the number 10.

options.label: C
options.text: The joke can be generalized to any base, where the number 10 in base b equals b in base 10.

options.text: Because Oct 31 equals Dec 25 in hexadecimal.

options.label: D
options.text: Because Oct 31 equals Dec 25 in binary.

title: Big rig myths: bicycle drafting

multiple-choice.question: What was the myth that the MythBusters team tested in this episode?

options.label: B
options.text: The myth that cyclists can get up to crazy speeds by drafting behind big rigs.

options.label: C
options.text: The myth that heart rate monitors are not accurate.

options.label: D
options.text: The myth that cycling is not a good exercise.

multiple-choice.question: What was the speed at which Tori rode the bike during the test?
What was used to measure Tori's energy expenditure during the test?

options.label: A
options.text: It was higher than during the first test.

options.label: B
options.text: It was lower than during the first test.

options.label: C
options.text: It remained the same as during the first test.

multiple-choice.question: What did the results of the test suggest?

options.label: A
options.text: That drafting behind a big rig has no effect on a cyclist's energy expenditure.

options.label: B
options.text: That drafting behind a big rig has a negative effect on a cyclist's energy expenditure.

options.label: C
options.text: That drafting behind a big rig can indeed provide an advantage to cyclists.

options.label: D
options.text: That cycling is not a good exercise.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the first test without a big rig?

options.label: A
options.text: To test the effect of drafting behind a big rig on a cyclist's energy expenditure.

options.label: B
options.text: To test the accuracy of the heart rate monitor.

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a control for the second test with a big rig.

options.label: D
options.text: To test the effect of speed on a cyclist's energy expenditure.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Tori's speed during the second test with a big rig?

options.label: A
options.text: It was lower than during the first test.

options.label: B
options.text: It was higher than during the first test.

options.label: C
options.text: It remained the same as during the first test.

multiple-choice.question: What did Tori feel during the second test with a big rig?

options.label: A
options.text: He felt like he was pumping the entire time.

options.label: B
options.text: He felt like he was coasting most of the time.

options.label: C
options.text: He felt like he was not using any energy.

options.label: D
options.text: He felt like he was not able to maintain his speed.

What was the verdict of the test?

options.label: A
options.text: That the myth was not plausible.

options.label: D
options.text: That cycling is not a good exercise.
